Actually, the universal rate of expansion differs by cosmic area, as gravity is the main factor that dictates the rate of that expansion. 


Now if you'd like to know something *truly* spooky, it's that the rate of expansion doesn't remain constant, and actually increases with each passing moment. Eventually, the rate of expansion will surpass the speed of light.

That means eventually, light won't be able to travel anymore as it's outpaced by the speed of expansion, meaning that thermal energy becomes nullified, and all matter in the universe instantly ceases to exist, and over time, so do all forms of energy, causing the death of reality.

The universe is space-time.  Everything (light, photons, particles, matter) within the fabric of space-time (inertial reference frame) is bound by the speed of light according to special relativity.  But space-time itself follows general relativity which has no inertial reference frame.   The fabric of space-time can travel or expand faster than light.  Thus the universe or the fabric of space-time expanded much faster than the speed of light shortly after the Big Bang.  This explains how something can be more than 13.8 billion light years away.
The point in space where the light originated is now 20 billion light years away.  It was much closer in the past when the event that created that light took place.

Space has been expanding since the beginning of time.

Imagine taking a rubber band and cutting it with some scissors. Now take each end. And slowly stretch it out. This represents space expanding. Now imagine a tiny little car driving along your rubber band. This represents light. 

The car doesn't have very far to travel at the start of the stretching of the rubber band. As the rubber band stretches farther and farther apart, the car has to travel ever farther to reach its destination. 

Since the car is traveling the whole time, it covers a lot of ground at first. So, by the end of the journey, when the rubber band is fully stretched, it will have taken less time to travel that distance than if the rubber band had been fully stretched from the start.

The universe is doing the same thing as the rubber band, except the rubber band is space and its happening in 3 dimensions rather than 1.

context: Now I don't claim to be a physicist or an astronomer, but I did take physics,calculus, and a course in stellar evolution in college, though that was 25 years ago. Someone please explain to me how a gamma-ray burst can originate some 20 Billion Light Years away from Earth, when the Universe is supposedly 13.8 Billion years old. Was this burst created before the Big Bang? If you tell me that the gamma-rays were effected by various gravitational fields along the way, I can understand that; but they would have had to be curved by gravity so many times and in such a dramatic arc that this explanation seems unlikely to me. I know there is an explanation; I just don't see it.

replies.context: Maybe it went around twice.....
It was only 1 billion LY away.  I suspect a typo that has been corrected, as I never saw the 20 billion number.

The Big Bang itself expanded much faster than the speed of light. But this only means that "nothing can go faster than light." Since nothing is just empty space or vacuum, it can expand faster than light since no material object is breaking the light barrier.

The expansion of the universe after the bid bang happened in an Infinitesimally small fraction of a second after the Big Bang happened.  The expansion started when the universe was smaller than the size of a proton and continued to when it was the size of a baseball.  The speed of light barrier refers to maximum speed of light through space at 186,000 miles/sec.  That did not apply to the expansion of the universe since it refered to the expansion of space itself, not of a light photon.

That still doesn't make sense to me because during the Big Bang every particle of being was rapidly taking on mass; therefore, by the time those particles were spread out merely the distance of the Earth's diameter, the amount of mass would have forced the obeyance of the speed of light. Moreover, the Big Bang itself would have to, by definition, exist in some kind of "space." The rapid expansion of matter simply began filling the preexisting "space." The convoluted explanations we hear from astronomers and physicists regarding the nature of the Big Bang mostly sounds like inverse logic to me. They affirm the existence of the primordial atom, then try and explain what happened by relying on what they see now. There never is an explanation of what it was that actually expanded. My initial question still stands. How does something exist 20 Billion light years ago in a Universe that is only 13.8 Billion years old. I think most physicists and astronomers just spout a lot of jargon out there because of their own hubris. Just because our brand of logic works on this world and in this galaxy, doesn't mean it works in a galaxy or a part of the Universe 500 million light years away from us. I mean, physics (read: logic) breaks down inside a Black Hole, right? So, there's a precedent for such a phenomenon. Astronomy and physics is mostly a lot of fun to think about, but its fundamental core is something we can never know in a Billion lifetimes.

I am like you, an amateur astronomer.  I have looked in the internet for other articles about the gamma-ray burst, to see if they caught their typo about the 20 billion lightyear quote.  But no such luck.  It looks like the original article had the typo, and everyone else copied their article 'word for word' and thus perpetuated the typo throughout the internet.  Since the story is less than one day old, the editors have yet to discover their brain fart.

Mar 08, 2021 ¬∑ For every megaparsec ‚Äî 3.3 million light years, or 3 billion trillion kilometers ‚Äî from Earth, the universe is expanding an extra 73.3 ¬±2.5 kilometers per second. replies.context: "Warp factor" had different meanings in Star Trek TOS (the original series) and Star Trek TNG (The Next Generation), but in neither of them does warp factor 10 equal ten times the speed of light.  In TOS, warp factor X equals X^3 times the speed of light, so warp factor 10 would be 1000 times the speed of light.  In TNG there was no simple formula, but warp factor 10 was infinite velocity (and unattainable).
